publicationStmt.p: Assignment for ENGL 340, SUNY Geneseo, Spring 2020

sourceDesc.bibl: A page from HM 924, the manuscript of Walden, "Solitude," Page 2, Changes in Version A

zone.note: We are transcribing the changes to page 2 of "Solitude" from Version A of Waleden
zone.line: rabbit, roam the fields and woods
without fearWe associate wildness with the night and silence.

line.del: But the repose is never complete;

zone.line: nature has her watchmen who are
links connecting the days of ani-
mated life.

zone.note: In this version, paragraph two has not been written yet. It skips directly to what is eventually known as the third paragraph in this chapter
zone.line: There seems always to be sufficient
space about us. Our horizon is never
quite at our elbows. The thick wood is
not just at my door, nor the
pond, but somewhat is always
clearing,and familiar and worn
by us appropriated and fenced
in some way and familiar and worn by
us; and reclaimed from Nature. For
what reason have I this vast
range and circuit, in nature—
a square mile and more of un—
frequented forest, for my privacy,
abandoned to me by men?Surely
we do not live crowded.My
nearest neighbor is more than
a mile distant, and no house is visible
from any place but the hill-tops within half a mile of my own.
I have my horizon bounded by woods
all to myself; I have a distant
view of railroad where it
touches the pond on the one hand,
and of the fence which skirts
the woodland road on the other.
